Article: 79. Constitution of Parliament There shall be a Parliament for the Union which shall consist of the President and two Houses to be known respectively as the council of States and the House of the People
Title: Article 79 - The Constitution of Parliament
Description:
India’s Parliament consists of:
The President of India.
Two Houses:
Council of States (Rajya Sabha).
House of the People (Lok Sabha).

Article:
80. Composition of the Council of States
 (1) The Council of States shall consist of
 (a) twelve members to be nominated by the President in accordance with the provisions of clause ( 3 ); and
 (b) not more than two hundred and thirty eight representatives of the States and of the Union territories
 (2) The allocation of seats in the Council of States to be filled by representatives of the States and of the Union territories shall be in accordance with the provisions in that behalf contained in the fourth Schedule
 (3) The members to be nominated by the President under sub clause (a) of clause ( 1 ) shall consist of persons having special knowledge or practical experience in respect of such matters as the following, namely: Literature, science, art and social service
 (4) The representatives of each State in the council of States shall be elected by the elected members of the Legislative Assembly of the State in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote
 (5) The representatives of the Union Territories in the council of States shall be chosen in such manner as Parliament may by law prescribe
Title: Article 80 - Composition of the Council of States (Rajya Sabha)
Description:
The Rajya Sabha has two types of members:

Nominated Members:
The President selects 12 members who are experts in fields like literature, science, art, or social service.
Elected Members:
Not more than 238 members are chosen to represent States and Union Territories.
Seats for States and Union Territories:

The number of seats for each State and Union Territory is listed in the Fourth Schedule of the Constitution.
How Members Are Chosen:

For States:
Members are elected by the State’s Legislative Assembly through proportional representation using the single transferable vote system.
For Union Territories:
Parliament decides the method of selection.

Article:
81. Composition of the House of the People
 (1) Subject to the provisions of Article 331 the House of the People shall consist of
 (a) not more than five hundred and thirty members chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies in the States, and
 (b) not more than twenty members to represent the Union territories, chosen in such manner as parliament may by law provide
 (2) For the purposes of sub clause (a) of clause ( 1 ) (a) there shall be allotted to each State a number of seats in the House of the People in such manner that the ratio between that number and the population of the State is, so far as practicable, the same for all States; and
 (b) each State shall be divided into territorial constituencies in such manner that the ratio between the population of each constituency and th number of seats allotted to it is, so far as practicable, the same throughout the State: Provided that the provisions of sub clause (a) of this clause shall not be applicable for the purpose of allotment of seats in the House of the People to any State so long as the population of that State does not exceed six millions
 (3) In this article, the expression population means the population as ascertained at the last preceding census of which the relevant figures have been published: Provided that the reference in this clause to the last preceding census of which the relevant figures have been published shall, until the relevant figures for the first census taken after the year 2000 have been published, be construed as a reference to the 1971 census
Title: Article 81 - Composition of the House of the People (Lok Sabha)
Description:
The Lok Sabha has:

Directly Elected Members:
Not more than 530 members are elected directly from the States.
Union Territory Representatives:
Not more than 20 members represent the Union Territories, chosen in a way decided by Parliament.
Allotment of Seats and Constituencies:

Each State gets a number of seats based on its population, ensuring fairness across all States.
States are divided into areas called territorial constituencies, and each constituency’s population is roughly equal.
Exceptions for Small States:

States with a population under 6 million don’t follow these rules strictly.
Population for Allotment:

Population data comes from the 1971 census, until new census figures are published after the year 2000.

Article: 82. Readjustment after each census Upon the completion of each census, the allocation of seats in the House of the People to the States and the division of each State into territorial constituencies shall be readjusted by such authority and in such manner as Parliament may by law determine: Provided that such readjustment shall not affect representation in the House of the People until the dissolution of the then existing House: Provided further that such readjustment shall take effect from such date as President may, by order, specify and until such readjustment takes effect, any election to the House may be held on the basis of the territorial constituencies existing before such readjustment: Provided also that until the relevant figures for the first census taken after the year 2000 have been published, it shall not be necessary to readjust the allocation of seats in the House of the People to the States and the division of each State into territorial constituencies under this article
Title: Article 82 - Readjustment After Each Census
Description:
After every census, Parliament decides how to:

Reassign the number of seats for each State in the Lok Sabha.
Redraw constituency boundaries within each State.
Timing:

Any changes will only apply after the current Lok Sabha’s term ends.
These adjustments come into effect on a date chosen by the President.
Special Provision for Post-2000 Census:

Until data from a census after 2000 is published, no changes are required in seat allocation or constituency boundaries.

Article:
83. Duration of Houses of Parliament
 (1) The council of States shall not be subject to dissolution, but as nearly as possible one third of the members thereof shall retire as soon as may be on the expiration of every second year in accordance with the provisions made in that behalf by Parliament by law
 (2) The House of the People, unless sooner dissolved, shall continue for five years from the date appointed for its first meeting and no longer and the expiration of the said period of five years shall operate as a dissolution of the House: Provided that the said period may, while a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, be extended by Parliament by law for a period not exceeding one year as a time and not extending in any case beyond a period of six months after s the Proclamation has ceased to operate
Title: Article 83 - Duration of the Houses of Parliament
Description:
Rajya Sabha (Council of States):

It is a permanent body and never dissolves.
However, one-third of its members retire every two years, and new members are elected or nominated to replace them.
Lok Sabha (House of the People):

Its term is 5 years, starting from its first meeting, unless dissolved earlier.
During a national emergency, its term can be extended by Parliament:
By 1 year at a time.
The extension cannot go beyond 6 months after the emergency ends.

Article:
84. Qualification for membership of Parliament A person shall not be qualified to be chosen to fill a seat in Parliament unless he
 (a) is a citizen of India, and makes and subscribes before some person authorised in that behalf by the Election Commission an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule;
 (b) is, in the case of a seat in the Council of States, not less than thirty years of age and, in the case of a seat in the House of the People, not less than twenty five years of age; and
 (c) possesses such other qualifications as may be prescribed in that behalf by or under any law made by Parliament
Title: Article 84 - Qualification for Membership of Parliament
Description:
To become a member of Parliament, a person must:

Be a Citizen of India:
The person must take an oath or affirmation as prescribed in the Third Schedule of the Constitution.
Meet the Age Requirement:
For Rajya Sabha: At least 30 years old.
For Lok Sabha: At least 25 years old.
Other Qualifications:
Parliament may pass laws specifying additional qualifications for eligibility.

Article:
85. Sessions of Parliament, prorogation and dissolution
 (1) The President shall form time to time summon each House of Parliament to meet at such time and place as he thinks fit, but six months shall not intervene between its last sitting in one session and the date appointed for its first sitting in the next session
 (2) The President may from time to time
 (a) prorogue the Houses or either House;
 (b) dissolve the House of the People
Title: Article 85 - Sessions of Parliament, Prorogation, and Dissolution
Description:
Summoning of Sessions:
The President decides when and where Parliament will meet, but there cannot be more than 6 months between the last sitting of one session and the first sitting of the next.
Prorogation and Dissolution:
The President can:
Prorogue (end a session) either or both Houses.
Dissolve the Lok Sabha (House of the People), which ends its term.

Article:
86. Right of President to address and send messages to Houses
 (1) The President may address either House of Parliament or both Houses assembled together, and for that purpose require the attendance of members
 (2) The President may send messages to either House of Parliament, whether with respect to a Bill then pending in Parliament or otherwise, and a House to which any message is so sent shall with all convenient dispatch consider any matter required by the message to be taken into consideration
Title: Article 86 - Right of the President to Address and Send Messages
Description:
Addressing Parliament:
The President can address either House or both Houses together and can require members to attend for this purpose.
Sending Messages:
The President can send messages to either House about a Bill or other matters.
The House must consider the message quickly.

Article:
87. Special address by the President
 (1) At the commencement of the first session after each general election to the House of the People and at the commencement of the first session of each year the President shall address both Houses of Parliament assembled together and inform Parliament of the causes of its summons
 (2) Provision shall be made by rules regulating the procedure of either House for the allotment of time for discussion of the matters referred to in such address
Title: Article 87 - Special Address by the President
Description:
Occasions for Special Address:
At the start of the first session after a general election to the Lok Sabha.
At the start of the first session each year.
Contents:
The President explains why Parliament has been summoned.
Discussion of the Address:
Rules are made to allow time for discussion of the matters mentioned in the address.

Article: 88. Rights of Ministers and Attorney General in respects Houses Every Minister and the Attorney General of India shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of either House, any joint sitting of the Houses, and any committee of Parliament of which he may be named a member, but shall not by virtue of this article be entitled to vote Officers of Parliament
Title: Article 88 - Rights of Ministers and Attorney General in Parliament
Description:
Who Can Participate:
Ministers and the Attorney General of India can:
Speak in any House of Parliament, joint sittings, or committees where they are members.
They cannot vote unless they are elected members of the respective House.

Article:
89. The Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the council of States
 (1) The Vice President of India shall be ex officio Chairman of the Council of States
 (2) The council of States shall, as soon as may be, choose a member of the council to be Deputy an thereof and, so often as the office of Deputy Chairman becomes vacant, the council shall choose another member to be Deputy chairman thereof
Title: Article 89 - Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Rajya Sabha (Council of States)
Description:
Chairman:
The Vice President of India is the ex-officio Chairman of the Rajya Sabha.
Deputy Chairman:
The Rajya Sabha elects one of its members as the Deputy Chairman.
If the Deputy Chairman’s post becomes vacant, a new one is elected.

Article:
90. Vacation and resignation of, and removal from, the office of Deputy Chairman A member holding office as Deputy chairman of the Council of States
 (a) shall vacate his office if he cease to be a member of the Council;
 (b) may at any time, by writing under his hand addressed to the Chairman, resign his office; and
 (c) may be removed from his office by a resolution of the Council passed by a majority of all the then members of the Council: Provided that no resolution for the purpose of clause (c) shall be moved unless at least fourteen days notice has been given of the intention to move the resolution
Title: Article 90 - Removal of the Deputy Chairman of Rajya Sabha
Description:
The Deputy Chairman must leave office if:

No Longer a Member: They stop being a Rajya Sabha member.
Resignation: They resign by writing to the Chairman.
Removal: They are removed by a majority vote in the Rajya Sabha.
Notice for Removal:

At least 14 days’ notice is needed to move a resolution for removal.

Article:
91. Power of the Deputy chairman or other person to perform the duties of the office of, or to act as, Chairman
 (1) While the office of Chairman is vacant, or during any period when the vice President is acting as, or discharging the functions of, President, the duties of the office shall be performed by the Deputy chairman, or, if the office of Deputy chairman is also vacant, by such member of the council of States as the President may appoint for the purpose
 (2) During the absence of the chairman from any sitting of the council of States the Deputy chairman, or, if he is also absent, such person as may be determined by the rules of procedure of the council, or, if no such person is present, such other person as may be determined by the council, shall act as Chairman
Title: Article 91 - Acting as Chairman in Special Circumstances
Description:
Vacancy or Absence of Chairman:

If the Vice President (Chairman) is unavailable or the position is vacant, the Deputy Chairman acts as Chairman.
If both positions are vacant, the President appoints a member to act as Chairman temporarily.
Rules for Absence in Sittings:

If both the Chairman and Deputy Chairman are absent, another person selected by the Rajya Sabha rules or its members will preside.

Article:
92. The Chairman or the Deputy chairman not to preside while a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration
 (1) At any sitting of the Council of States, while any resolution for the removal of the Vice President from his office is under consideration, the Chairman, or while any resolution for the removal of the Deputy Chairman from his office is under consideration, the Deputy Chairman, shall not, though he is present, preside, and the provisions of clause ( 2 ) of Article 91 shall apply in relation to every such sitting as they apply in relation to a sitting from which the chairman, or, as the case may be, the Deputy Chairman, is absent
 (2) The Chairman shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in proceedings of, the Council of States while any resolution for the removal of the Vice President from his office is under consideration in the Council, but, notwithstanding anything in Article 100, shall not be entitled to vote at all on such resolution or on any other matter during such proceedings
Title: Article 92 - Restrictions During Removal Proceedings
Description:
Chairman and Deputy Chairman Cannot Preside:

During discussions about their removal, they cannot preside over the sitting.
The rules from Article 91(2) apply for selecting someone else to preside.
Participation Without Voting:

The Chairman or Deputy Chairman can participate in discussions about their removal but cannot vote on the resolution or any other matter during such proceedings.

Article: 93. The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House of the People The House of the People shall, as soon as may be, choose two members of the House to be respectively Speaker and Deputy Speaker thereof and, so often as the office of Speaker or Deputy Speaker becomes vacant, the House shall choose another member to be Speaker or Deputy Speaker, as the case may be
Title: Article 93 - Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Lok Sabha (House of the People)
Description:
Election of Speaker and Deputy Speaker:

The Lok Sabha elects two members to act as:
Speaker: Presides over the House.
Deputy Speaker: Acts as Speaker in their absence.
Filling Vacancies:

If the Speaker or Deputy Speaker’s office becomes vacant, the House elects a new member for the position.

Article:
94. Vacation and resignation of, and removal from, the offices of Speaker and Deputy Speaker A member holding office as Speaker or Deputy Speaker of the House of the People
 (a) shall vacate his office if he ceases to be a member of the House of the People;
 (b) may at any time, by writing under his hand addressed, if such member is the Speaker, to the Deputy Speaker, and if such member is the Deputy Speaker, to the Speaker, resign his office; and
 (c) may be removed from his office by a resolution of the House of the People passed by a majority of all the then members of the House: Provided that no resolution for the purpose of clause (c) shall be moved unless at least fourteen days notice has been given of the intention to move the resolution: Provided further that, whenever the House of the People is dissolved, the Speaker shall not vacate his office until immediately before the first meeting of the House of the People after the dissolution
Title: Article 94: Vacation, Resignation, and Removal of Speaker and Deputy Speaker
Description:
This article talks about what happens when the Speaker (the person who leads the House of the People, or Lok Sabha) or the Deputy Speaker (the person who helps the Speaker) needs to leave their job.

They leave if they stop being a member of the House.
They can also quit whenever they want by writing a letter.
They can be removed from the position by a vote from the members of the House, but the members need to give 14 days' notice before starting the vote.

Article:
95. Power of the Deputy Speaker or other person to perform the duties of the office of, or to act as, Speaker
 (1) While the office of Speaker is vacant, the duties of the office shall be performed by the Deputy Speaker or, if the office of Deputy Speaker is also vacant, by such member of the House of the People as the President may appoint for the purpose
 (2) During the absence of the Speaker from any sitting of the House of the People the Deputy Speaker or, if he is also absent, such person as may be determined by the rules of procedure of the House, or, if no such person is present, such other person as may be determined by the House, shall act as Speaker
Title: Article 95: Power of Deputy Speaker to Act as Speaker
Description:
This article explains what happens if the Speaker is not available.

If the Speaker isn't there, the Deputy Speaker takes over.
If both the Speaker and Deputy Speaker are not available, the President can choose someone to act as the Speaker until one of them returns.

Article:
96. The Speaker or the Deputy Speaker not to preside while a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration
 (1) At any sitting of the House of the People, while any resolution for the removal of the Speaker from his office is under consideration, the Speaker, or while any resolution for the removal of the Deputy Speaker from his office is under consideration, the Deputy Speaker, shall not, though he is present, preside, and the provisions of clause ( 2 ) of Article 95 shall apply in relation to every such sitting as they apply in relation to a sitting from which the Speaker, or, as the case may be, the Deputy Speaker, is absent
 (2) The Speaker shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, the House of the People while any resolution for his removal from office is under consideration in the House and shall, notwithstanding anything in Article 100, be entitled to vote only in the first instance on such resolution or on any other matter during such proceedings but not in the case of an equality of votes
Title: Article 96: Speaker and Deputy Speaker Not to Preside Over Their Removal
Description:
If the House is discussing whether to remove the Speaker or Deputy Speaker, they cannot lead or "preside" over the meeting.
The Speaker can still speak and take part in the discussion, but only vote if there is a tie.

Article: 97. Salaries and allowances of the Chairman and Deputy Chairman and the Speaker and Deputy Speaker There shall be paid to the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the council of States, and to the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of the House of the People, such salaries and allowances as may be respectively fixed by Parliament by law and, until provision in that behalf is so made, such salaries and allowances as are specified in the Second Schedule
Title: Article 97: Salaries of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker
Description: This article says that the Speaker and Deputy Speaker get a salary (money for their work) decided by Parliament.

Article:
98. Secretariat of Parliament
 (1) Each House of Parliament shall have a separate secretariat staff: Provided that nothing in this clause shall be construed as preventing the creation of posts common to both Houses of Parliament
 (2) Parliament may by law regulate the recruitment, and the conditions of service of persons appointed, to the secretarial staff of either House of Parliament
 (3) Until provision is made by Parliament under clause ( 2 ), the President may, after consultation with the Speaker of the House of the People or the chairman of the council of States, as the case may be, make rules regulating the recruitment, and the conditions of service of persons appointed, to the secretarial staff of the House of the People or the council of States, and any rules so made shall have effect subject to the provisions of any law made under the said clause Conduct of Business
Title: Article 98: Secretariat of Parliament
Description:
This article talks about the secretaries and staff who work in Parliament.

Each House (Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha) has its own team of workers.
The President can make rules about how these workers are hired and what their jobs are until Parliament decides.

Article: 99. Oath or affirmation by members Every member of either House of Parliament shall, before taking his seat, make and subscribe before the President, or some person appointed in that behalf by him, an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule
Title: Article 99: Oath or Affirmation by Members
Description: This article says that before a member can sit in Parliament, they need to take an oath or promise to do their job properly in front of the President or someone the President appoints.

Article:
100. Voting in Houses, power of Houses to act notwithstanding vacancies and quorum
 (1) Save as otherwise provided in this Constitution, all questions at any sitting of either House or joint sitting of the Houses shall be determined by a majority of votes of the members present and voting, other than the Speaker or person acting as Chairman or Speaker The Chairman or Speaker, or person acting as such, shall not vote in the first instance, but shall have and exercise a casting vote in the case of an equality of votes
 (2) Either House of Parliament shall have power to act notwithstanding any vacancy in the membership thereof, and any proceedings in Parliament shall be valid notwithstanding that it is discovered subsequently that some person who was not entitled so to do sat or voted or otherwise took part in the proceedings
 (3) Until Parliament by law otherwise provides, the quorum to constitute a meeting of either House of Parliament shall be one tenth of the total number of members of the House
 (4) If at any time during a meeting of a House there is no quorum, it shall be the duty of the chairman or Speaker, or person acting as such, either to adjourn the House or to suspend the meeting until there is a quorum
Title: Article 100: Voting in the Houses of Parliament
Description:
Most decisions in Parliament are made by voting.
The Speaker or Chairman doesn't vote unless there's a tie, and then they have the casting vote, which is the deciding vote.
Even if there are empty seats in Parliament, it can still make decisions.
If there aren't enough members present to make a decision, the meeting can be suspended until there are enough people.

Article:
101. Vacation of seats
 (1) No person shall be a member of both Houses of Parliament and provision shall be made by Parliament by law for the vacation by a person who is chosen a member of both Houses of his seat in one House or the other
 (2) No person shall be a member both of Parliament and of a House of the Legislature of a State and if a person is chosen a member both of Parliament and of a House of the Legislature of a State, then, at the expiration of such period as may be specified in rules made by the President, that persons seat in Parliament shall become vacant, unless he has previously resigned his seat in the Legislature of the State
 (3) If a member of either House of Parliament
 (a) becomes subject to any of the disqualification s mentioned in clause ( 1 ) or clause ( 2 ) of Article 102, or
 (b) resigns his seat by writing under his hand addressed to the Chairman or the Speaker, as the as may be, and his resignation is accepted by the chairman or the Speaker, as the case may be, his seat shall thereupon become vacant: Provided that in the case of any resignation referred to in sub clause (b), if from information received or otherwise and after making such inquiry as he thinks fit, the chairman or the Speaker, as the case may be, is satisfied that such resignation is not voluntary or genuine, he shall not accept such resignation
 (4) If for a period of sixty days a member of either House of Parliament is without permission of the House absent from all meetings thereof, the House may declare his seat vacant: Provided that in computing the said period of sixty days no account shall be taken of any period during which the House is prorogued or is adjourned for more than four consecutive days
Title: Article 101: Vacation of Seats
Description:
No person can be a member of both Houses of Parliament:

If someone is elected to both Houses, Parliament will make a law that forces the person to give up their seat in one of the Houses.
No person can be a member of both Parliament and a State Legislature:

If someone is elected to both Parliament and a State Legislature, they must give up their seat in Parliament after a certain period (as decided by the President), unless they resign from the State Legislature first.
Disqualification or resignation:

A person’s seat will become vacant if:
They become disqualified (as mentioned in Article 102).
They voluntarily resign by submitting a written resignation to the Chairman or Speaker, and it is accepted by them.
Important note: If the Chairman or Speaker believes the resignation is not voluntary or genuine, they can refuse to accept it.
Absence for 60 days:

If a member is absent from all meetings of either House of Parliament for 60 days without permission, their seat can be declared vacant.
The 60-day period doesn't include the time when the House is prorogued (temporarily suspended) or adjourned for more than four consecutive days.

Title: Article 102: Disqualifications for Membership
Description:
This article outlines the conditions under which a person can be disqualified from being elected to, or continuing as, a member of either House of Parliament (Lok Sabha or Rajya Sabha).

Disqualifications under Clause 1:
A person will be disqualified from being chosen as a member of Parliament or from holding a seat if they:

Hold an office of profit under the government:

A person cannot be a member if they hold any government job (either at the national or state level) that provides a salary or benefits, unless Parliament specifically says that job doesn't disqualify them.
Are of unsound mind:

If a person is mentally unfit and a court has declared them so, they cannot become or remain a member of Parliament.
Are an undischarged insolvent:

If a person is bankrupt and has not been discharged from their debts, they are disqualified.
Are not a citizen of India:

If a person is not an Indian citizen, or if they have taken the citizenship of another country, or if they owe allegiance to a foreign country, they cannot be a member of Parliament.
Are disqualified under any other law made by Parliament:

If any law passed by Parliament says that a person is disqualified for some reason not listed here, they will be disqualified.
Explanation: This clause also specifies that a person who is a Minister (either for the Union or a State) will not be considered as holding an office of profit just because they are a Minister. Ministers are exempted from this particular rule.

Disqualification under Clause 2:
A person can also be disqualified from being a member of Parliament if they are disqualified under the Tenth Schedule. This refers to the law regarding defection. If a member of Parliament joins another political party or changes parties in violation of the rules in the Tenth Schedule, they can be disqualified.

Article:
103. Decision on questions as to disqualifications of members
 (1) If any question arises as to whether a member of either House of Parliament has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause ( 1 ) of Article 102, the question shall be referred for the decision of the President and his decision shall be final
 (2) Before giving any decision on any such question, the President shall obtain the opinion of the Election Commission and shall act according to such opinion
Title: Article 103: Decision on Disqualifications
Description:
If there's a question about whether a member of Parliament is disqualified (not eligible to be a member), the President makes the final decision.
Before deciding, the President will ask the Election Commission for advice.

Article: 104. Penalty for sitting and voting before making oath or affirmation under Article 99 or when not qualified or when disqualified If a person sits or votes as a member of either House of Parliament before he has complied with the requirements of Article 99, or when he knows that he is not qualified or that he is disqualified for membership thereof, or that he is prohibited from so doing by the provisions of any law made by Parliament, he shall be liable in respect of each day on which he so sits or votes to a penalty of five hundred rupees to be recovered as a debt due to the Union Powers, Privileges and Immunities of Parliament and its Members
Title: Article 104: Penalty for Sitting or Voting Without Qualifying
Description: If someone who is not qualified to be in Parliament sits or votes, they will have to pay a fine of 500 rupees for each day they do so.

Article:
105. Powers, privileges, etc of the Houses of Parliament and of the members and committees thereof
 (1) Subject to the provisions of this constitution and the rules and standing orders regulating the procedure of Parliament, there shall be freedom of speech in Parliament
 (2) No member of Parliament shall be liable to any proceedings in any court in respect of anything said or any vote given by him in Parliament or any committee thereof, and no person shall be so liable in respect of the publication by or under the authority of either House of Parliament of any report, paper, votes or proceedings
 (3) In other respects, the powers, privileges and immunities of each House of Parliament, and of the members and the committees of each House, shall be such as may from time to time be defined by Parliament by law, and, until so defined shall be those of that House and of its members and committees immediately before the coming into force of Section 15 of the Constitution (Forty fourth Amendment) Act 1978
 (4) The provisions of clauses ( 1 ), ( 2 ) and ( 3 ) shall apply in relation to persons who by virtue of this constitution have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, a House of Parliament or any committee thereof as they apply in relation to members of Parliament
Title: Article 105: Powers, Privileges, etc., of the Houses of Parliament and its Members
Description:
This article defines the powers and privileges of Parliament, its members, and its committees. It grants certain rights to Parliament to ensure its smooth functioning and protection of its members.

Clause 1: Freedom of Speech in Parliament
Freedom of Speech: Members of Parliament have the right to speak freely in Parliament. This means they can express their views on any topic without fear of legal action, but their speech is still subject to the rules of the Parliament.
However, this freedom is not absolute and is subject to the rules and standing orders (procedures) that Parliament follows. For example, there may be limits to what can be discussed or how discussions should be conducted.
Clause 2: Immunity from Legal Proceedings
Immunity from Court Action: No member of Parliament can be sued or face any legal proceedings in a court for anything they say in Parliament or for any vote they give. This means they have legal immunity for their actions within Parliament.
Publication Immunity: Similarly, if anything published by or under the authority of Parliament, such as reports, papers, or proceedings, it cannot be used against anyone in court.
Clause 3: Powers, Privileges, and Immunities Defined by Parliament
The powers and privileges of the Parliament, its members, and its committees are decided by Parliament itself through laws.
Until these laws are made, the powers and privileges are the same as they were before 1978, when a specific amendment (Forty-Fourth Amendment) came into force.
This means that the legal rights and protections for members of Parliament (such as their ability to speak freely, etc.) were established before 1978 and continue to apply unless Parliament passes new laws to change them.
Clause 4: Application to Other People
The provisions mentioned in Clauses 1, 2, and 3 (freedom of speech, immunity from legal action, and powers/privileges) apply not just to members of Parliament, but also to those who have the right to speak in Parliament or take part in parliamentary proceedings.
This means people like Ministers or other individuals allowed to participate in parliamentary debates or committees also have these protections and privileges.

Article: 106. Salaries and allowances of members Members of either House of Parliament shall be entitled to receive such salaries and allowances as may from time to time be determined by Parliament by law and, until provision in that in that respect is so made, allowances at such rates and upon such conditions as were immediately before the commencement of this Constitution applicable in the case of members of the Constituent Assembly of the Dominion of India Legislative Procedure
Title: Article 106: Salaries and Allowances of Members
Description: Members of Parliament are paid a salary and get allowances, which are determined by Parliament.

Article:
107. Provisions as to introduction and passing of Bills
 (1) Subject to the provisions of Articles 109 and 117 with respect to Money Bills and other financial Bills, a Bill may originate in either House of Parliament
 (2) Subject to the provisions of Article 108 and 109, a Bill shall not be deemed to have been passed by the Houses of Parliament unless it has been agreed to by both Houses, either without amendment or with such amendments only as are agreed by both Houses
 (3) A Bill pending in Parliament shall not lapse by reason of the prorogation of the Houses
 (4) A Bill pending in the Council of States which has not been passed by the House of the People shall not lapse on a dissolution of the House of the People
 (5) A Bill which is pending in the House of the People, or which having been passed by the House of the People is pending in the council of States, shall subject to the provisions of Article 108, lapse on a dissolution of the House of the People
Title: Article 107: Provisions as to Introduction and Passing of Bills
Description:
This article explains how a Bill (a proposed law) is introduced and passed in Parliament. It outlines the process and conditions under which a Bill moves between the two Houses of Parliament: the Lok Sabha (House of the People) and the Rajya Sabha (Council of States).

Clause 1: Origin of a Bill
Where a Bill Can Start: A Bill can be introduced in either the Lok Sabha or the Rajya Sabha. There is no rule that requires a Bill to start in one House over the other, except for Money Bills and other financial Bills, which have specific rules (mentioned in Articles 109 and 117).
Clause 2: Agreement Between Both Houses
Agreement Required for Passage: For a Bill to be passed, both Houses must agree to it. This can be with or without changes (amendments), but any amendments must be agreed upon by both Houses.
If the Lok Sabha agrees on a Bill with amendments, the Rajya Sabha must also agree on the same amendments (and vice versa). If they cannot agree, the Bill is not passed.
Money Bills (related to taxes, government spending, etc.) have separate rules.
Clause 3: Bills Not Lapsing Due to Prorogation
No Lapse During Prorogation: If a Bill is still being discussed or has not been passed by either House, it does not get canceled or "lapse" if the Parliament is prorogued (temporarily closed).
This ensures that the work on the Bill can continue after Parliament reopens.
Clause 4: Bills in Rajya Sabha When Lok Sabha is Dissolved
Bill Pending in Rajya Sabha and Lok Sabha Dissolved: If a Bill is still under discussion in the Rajya Sabha and has not yet been passed by the Lok Sabha, it does not lapse if the Lok Sabha is dissolved (disbanded).
This means the Bill can still continue its passage when the new Lok Sabha is formed.
Clause 5: Bills in Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha Dissolved
Bill Pending in Lok Sabha or Rajya Sabha and Dissolution of Lok Sabha: If a Bill is in the Lok Sabha or if it has been passed by the Lok Sabha and is still pending in the Rajya Sabha, it laps (ends) if the Lok Sabha is dissolved.
This means the Bill cannot continue unless reintroduced after the new Lok Sabha is formed.

Article:
108. Joint sitting of both Houses in certain cases
 (1) If after a Bill has been passed by one House and transmitted to the other House
 (a) the Bill is rejected by the other House; or
 (b) the Houses have finally disagreed as to the amendments to be made in the Bill; or
 (c) more than six months elapse from the date of the reception of the Bill by the other House without the Bill being passed by it the President may, unless the Bill has lapsed by reason of a dissolution of the House of the People, notify to the Houses by message if they are sitting or by public notification if they are not sitting, his intention to summon them to meet in a joint sitting for the purpose of deliberating and voting on the Bill: Provided that nothing in this clause shall apply to a Money Bill
 (2) In reckoning any such period of six months as is referred to in clause ( 1 ), no account shall be taken of any period during which the House referred to in sub clause (c) of that clause is prorogued or adjourned for more than four consecutive days
 (3) Where the President has under clause ( 1 ) notified his intention of summoning the Houses to meet in a joint sitting, neither House shall proceed further with the Bill, but the President may at any time after the date of his notification summon the Houses to meet in a joint sitting for the purpose specified in the notification and, if he does so, the Houses shall meet accordingly
 (4) If at the joint sitting of the two Houses the Bill, with such amendments, if any, as are agreed to in joint siting, is passed by a majority of the total number of members of both Houses present and voting, it shall be deemed for the purposes of this Constitution to have been passed by both Houses: Provided that a joint sitting
 (a) if the Bill, having been passed by one House, has not been passed by the other House with amendments and returned to the House in which it originated, no amendment shall be proposed to the Bill other than such amendments (if any) as are made necessary by the delay in the passage of the Bill;
 (b) if the Bill has been so passed and returned, only such amendments as aforesaid shall be proposed to the Bill and such other amendments as are relevant to the matters with respect to which the Houses have not agreed; and the decision of the person presiding as to the amendments which are admissible under this clause shall be final
 (5) A joint sitting may be held under this article and a Bill passed thereat, notwithstanding that a dissolution of the House of the People has intervened since the President notified his intention to summon the Houses to meet therein
Title: Article 108: Joint Sitting of Both Houses in Certain Cases
Description:
This article deals with a situation where both Houses of Parliament (the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha) are unable to agree on a Bill. In such cases, the President can call a Joint Sitting of both Houses to resolve the disagreement.

Clause 1: When a Joint Sitting Can Be Called
If a Bill has been passed by one House and sent to the other, and:
The Bill is rejected by the other House.
The two Houses cannot agree on amendments to the Bill.
More than six months pass after the Bill is sent to the other House, and that House has not passed the Bill.
In such situations, the President can decide to call a Joint Sitting of both Houses for discussion and voting on the Bill.
However, Money Bills (related to money, taxes, or government spending) are not included in this process.
Clause 2: Counting of Six Months
When counting the six months mentioned in Clause 1, you don’t count the time when the House is prorogued (temporarily closed) or adjourned for more than four consecutive days.
Clause 3: Procedure After the President’s Notification
If the President has decided to summon both Houses for a Joint Sitting, neither House can continue working on the Bill. Once the President makes this notification, they must wait for a Joint Sitting to take place.
The President can call the Joint Sitting at any time after notifying, and when the Houses meet, they will discuss and vote on the Bill.
Clause 4: Voting in the Joint Sitting
In the Joint Sitting, the Bill will be considered, and if a majority of the total members present and voting agree on the Bill (with or without amendments), the Bill is considered passed by both Houses.
Amendments to the Bill can be made during the Joint Sitting, but only under certain conditions:
If the Bill has passed in one House and not passed in the other House, the only changes that can be made are those necessary due to the delay in the Bill’s passage.
If the Bill has been passed and returned by the second House, only those amendments are allowed that relate to the disagreements between the Houses.
The decision on what amendments are allowed during this process is final and made by the presiding officer (the person leading the Joint Sitting).
Clause 5: Joint Sitting Despite Dissolution of Lok Sabha
A Joint Sitting can still take place even if the Lok Sabha is dissolved (ended before the session is over) after the President has decided to call the Joint Sitting.
In this case, the President’s notification still stands, and the Joint Sitting can proceed even after the dissolution of the Lok Sabha.
In simple terms:
When to Call a Joint Sitting: If the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha can’t agree on a Bill for various reasons (rejection, disagreements on changes, or delay), the President can call a Joint Sitting of both Houses to settle the matter.
Six-Month Rule: If the Bill is stuck for six months in one House, the President can step in, but time spent in prorogation or long adjournments isn’t counted.
Waiting for Joint Sitting: After the President’s decision, both Houses must wait for the Joint Sitting to discuss and vote on the Bill.
How the Bill is Passed: If most members of both Houses agree to the Bill in the Joint Sitting, it’s considered passed. The rules on amendments depend on whether the Bill has been passed in both Houses before or not.
Joint Sitting Despite Lok Sabha's Dissolution: If the Lok Sabha is dissolved, the Joint Sitting can still take place as long as the President has already decided to call it.

Article:
109. Special procedure in respect of Money Bills
 (1) A Money Bill shall not be introduced in the Council of States
 (2) After a Money Bill has been passed by the House of the People it shall be transmitted to the Council of States for its recommendations and the Council of States shall within a period of fourteen days from the date of its receipt of the Bill return the Bill to the house of the People with its recommendations and the House of the People may thereupon either accept or reject all or any of the recommendations of the Council of States
 (3) If the House of the People accepts any of the recommendations of the council of States, the Money Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses with the amendments recommended by the council of States and accepted by the House of the People
 (4) If the House of the People does not accept any of the recommendations of the council of States, the Money Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses in the form in which it was passed by the House of the People without any of the amendments recommended by the Council of States
 (5) If a Money Bill passed by the House of the People and transmitted to the council of States for its recommendations is not returned to the House of the People within the said period of fourteen days, it shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses at the expiration of the said period in the form in which it was passed by the House of the People
Title: Article 109: Special Procedure in Respect of Money Bills
Description:
This article sets out the special procedure for the passage of Money Bills through Parliament, outlining how the Lok Sabha (House of the People) and the Rajya Sabha (Council of States) deal with such Bills.

Clause 1: Where a Money Bill Can Be Introduced
A Money Bill can only be introduced in the Lok Sabha (House of the People).
It cannot be introduced in the Rajya Sabha (Council of States).
Clause 2: Sending a Money Bill to the Rajya Sabha
Once the Lok Sabha passes a Money Bill, it is sent to the Rajya Sabha for its recommendations.
The Rajya Sabha has 14 days to consider the Bill and send it back to the Lok Sabha with its recommendations.
The Rajya Sabha is required to act quickly within 14 days from receiving the Bill.
Clause 3: Accepting the Recommendations of the Rajya Sabha
If the Lok Sabha agrees to any of the recommendations made by the Rajya Sabha, the Money Bill will be passed by both Houses with the changes suggested by the Rajya Sabha that the Lok Sabha accepts.
Essentially, the Lok Sabha can accept or reject the changes the Rajya Sabha proposes, and the Bill becomes law with the agreed-upon amendments.
Clause 4: Rejecting the Recommendations of the Rajya Sabha
If the Lok Sabha rejects all the recommendations made by the Rajya Sabha, the Money Bill will be considered passed by both Houses in the exact form in which it was originally passed by the Lok Sabha.
In this case, the Rajya Sabha's recommendations are ignored, and the Bill is deemed passed without any changes.
Clause 5: Rajya Sabha Failing to Return the Bill
If the Rajya Sabha does not return the Money Bill to the Lok Sabha within 14 days (for any reason), the Bill is considered to be passed by both Houses in the form in which it was originally passed by the Lok Sabha.
This means that if the Rajya Sabha delays or does not act on a Money Bill, the Lok Sabha’s version of the Bill automatically becomes the final version after 14 days.
In simple terms:
Money Bills can only start in the Lok Sabha and not the Rajya Sabha.
After the Lok Sabha passes a Money Bill, the Rajya Sabha has 14 days to suggest changes (recommendations).
If the Lok Sabha agrees to any of those changes, the Money Bill is passed with those changes.
If the Lok Sabha rejects all the suggestions, the Bill passes in the form it was passed by the Lok Sabha.
If the Rajya Sabha does not act within 14 days, the Bill is automatically considered passed in the form it was passed by the Lok Sabha.

Title: Article 110: Definition of Money Bill
Description:
This article defines what constitutes a Money Bill and the process for its handling in Parliament.

Clause 1: What Makes a Bill a Money Bill?
A Bill is considered a Money Bill if it deals with any of the following financial matters:

(a) Taxes: Anything related to the imposition, abolition, remission, alteration, or regulation of taxes.
(b) Government Borrowing and Guarantees: Rules about how the Government of India borrows money or gives financial guarantees, or changes laws about financial obligations of the government.
(c) Funds Management: The custody and movement of money in key government funds (like the Consolidated Fund of India and the Contingency Fund of India), including deposits into or withdrawals from these funds.
(d) Appropriation of Money: How money from the Consolidated Fund of India is used (appropriated).
(e) Expenditure Charged on the Fund: Declaring specific expenditures as charged on the Consolidated Fund of India (like certain government expenses) or increasing such expenditures.
(f) Receipt and Audit of Money: The receipt, custody, or issue of government funds, and the auditing of accounts for the Union or any State.
(g) Any matter incidental to the above points.
Clause 2: What Is Not a Money Bill?
A Bill will not be considered a Money Bill if it deals with:

Imposing fines or penalties.
Charging fees for licenses or services.
Tax-related matters for local authorities (like municipal taxes) or for local purposes (as opposed to national taxes).
Clause 3: Dispute Over Whether a Bill is a Money Bill
If there is a dispute or confusion about whether a Bill is a Money Bill, the Speaker of the Lok Sabha will make the final decision.
The Speaker's decision is final and cannot be challenged.
Clause 4: Certification of a Money Bill
Every Money Bill must be certified by the Speaker of the Lok Sabha when it is transmitted to the Rajya Sabha and when it is presented to the President for assent.
The Speaker’s certificate verifies that the Bill is indeed a Money Bill.

Article: 111. Assent to Bills When a Bill has been passed by the Houses of Parliament, it shall be presented to the President, and the President shall declare either that he assents to the Bill, or that he withholds assent therefrom Provided that the President may, as soon as possible after the presentation to him of a Bill for assent, return the Bill if it is not a Money Bill to the Houses with a message requesting that they will reconsider the Bill or any specified provisions thereof and, in particular, will consider the desirability of introducing any such amendments as he may recommend in his message, and when a Bill is so returned, the Houses shall reconsider the Bill accordingly, and if the Bill is passed again by the Houses with or without amendment and presented to the President for assent, the President shall not withhold assent therefrom Procedures in Financial Matters
Title: Article 111 - Assent to Bills
Description:
After a bill is passed by both Houses of Parliament, it is sent to the President for approval (assent).
The President can either:
Approve the bill (assent).
Reject the bill (withhold assent).
Return the bill (except in case of money bills) for reconsideration by Parliament.
If Parliament passes the bill again after reconsideration, the President must give assent.

Article 112: Annual Financial Statement
This article explains how the Annual Financial Statement is prepared and presented by the President of India in Parliament, which is essentially the Budget of the Government of India. It outlines the estimated income and expenses for the upcoming financial year.

Clause 1: Presentation of the Annual Financial Statement
The President has to present a statement each year to both Houses of Parliament (the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha) showing the estimated receipts (income) and expenditure (spending) of the Government of India for the upcoming financial year.
This statement is referred to as the "Annual Financial Statement" (the Budget).
Clause 2: Breakdown of the Expenditure
The statement will show the estimated expenditure in two categories:
(a) Expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of India: This is a special category of expenditure that is automatically paid from the government's main account (Consolidated Fund) without needing Parliament’s approval each year.
(b) Other expenditure: This is the regular expenditure that requires Parliament’s approval.
Additionally, the statement must clearly show:
Expenditure on revenue account: This is for the day-to-day running of the government.
Other types of expenditure: This includes things like investments or capital expenses.
Clause 3: Expenditure Charged on the Consolidated Fund of India
Some expenditures are automatically paid from the Consolidated Fund of India and do not require annual approval from Parliament. These include:

(a) The President's emoluments: The salary, allowances, and office expenses related to the President's office.
(b) The salaries and allowances of key Parliament figures: This includes the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Council of States (Rajya Sabha), the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Lok Sabha.
(c) Debt Charges: These are payments the government makes to cover interest, sinking fund charges, and redemption of loans the government has taken.
(d) Salaries, allowances, and pensions of Judges:
Supreme Court Judges.
Federal Court Judges (for those who served before India became a Republic).
High Court Judges (for those who were serving before the Constitution came into effect).
(e) Salaries and pensions of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India (CAG).
(f) Payments to settle court judgments: If the government is required to pay a judgment or award given by a court or arbitral tribunal, that amount is also charged to the Consolidated Fund.
(g) Other expenditure: Any other types of expenditure that are either mentioned in the Constitution or have been designated by Parliament as being charged on the Consolidated Fund.

Article:
113. Procedure in Parliament with respect to estimates
 (1) So much of the estimates as relates to expenditure charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India shall not be submitted to the vote of Parliament, but nothing in this clause shall be construed as preventing the discussion in either House of Parliament of any of those estimates
 (2) So much of the said estimates as relates to other expenditure shall be submitted in the form of demands for grants to the House of the People, and the House of the People shall have power to assent, or to refuse to assent, to any demand, or to assent to any demand subject to a reduction of the amount specified therein
 (3) No demand for a grant shall be made except on the recommendation of the President
Title: Article 113: Procedure in Parliament with Respect to Estimates
Description:
Article 113 of the Indian Constitution outlines the process for approving government expenditure and the procedure that Parliament follows with respect to the estimates of expenditure presented in the Annual Financial Statement (the Union Budget).

Clause 1: Expenditure Charged on the Consolidated Fund of India
The estimates for expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of India (such as debt charges, salaries of the President, salaries of judges, etc.) are not voted on by Parliament.
However, discussion on these estimates is allowed in both Houses of Parliament (Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha).
In simple terms, while Parliament cannot vote to approve or reject these charges (as they are automatically paid), debate on them is still permitted.
Clause 2: Other Expenditure
The estimates for other expenditure (expenses that are not automatically charged on the Consolidated Fund) are presented as demands for grants to the Lok Sabha (House of the People).
Demands for grants refer to the specific requests made by the government for funding particular projects or activities.
The Lok Sabha has the power to:
Approve the demand for the full amount.
Reject the demand entirely.
Approve the demand but with a reduction in the amount requested.
This gives the Lok Sabha significant control over the allocation of funds for government programs.
Clause 3: Presidential Recommendation for Grants
A demand for a grant (a request for funds) cannot be made unless it is recommended by the President.
This ensures that the President has formal approval over the government’s request for funding before Parliament considers it.

Article:
114. Appropriation Bills
 (1) As soon as may be after the grants under article 113 have been made by the House of the People, there shall be introduced a Bill to provide for the appropriation out of the Consolidated Fund of India of all moneys required to meet
 (a) the grants so made by the House of the People; and
 (b) the expenditure charged on the Consolidated fund of India but not exceeding in any case the amount shown in the statement previously laid before Parliament
 (2) No amendment shall be proposed to any such Bill in either House of Parliament which will have the effect of varying the amount or altering the destination of any grant so made or of varying the amount of any expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of India, and the decision of the person presiding as to whether an amendment is inadmissible under this clause shall be final
 (3) Subject to the provisions of articles 115 and 116, no money shall be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund of India expect under appropriation made by law passed in accordance with the provisions of this article
Title: Article 114: Appropriation Bills
Description:
Article 114 of the Indian Constitution deals with the Appropriation Bill, which is a legal requirement for the government to access funds from the Consolidated Fund of India. It ensures that money can only be withdrawn for government spending if it is legally authorized through an appropriation process.

Clause 1: Introduction of the Appropriation Bill
Once grants (approved by the Lok Sabha, as per Article 113) are made, the Appropriation Bill is introduced. This Bill authorizes the government to withdraw money from the Consolidated Fund of India.
The purpose of the Bill is to:
Appropriate the grants already approved by the Lok Sabha (for specific projects or spending).
Appropriate the expenditure that is automatically charged on the Consolidated Fund of India (such as debt repayment or judicial salaries), but within the limits already set in the Annual Financial Statement (the Budget).
Example: If the Lok Sabha has approved a grant for education, the Appropriation Bill ensures that the money can be withdrawn from the fund to fulfill this purpose.
Clause 2: Restrictions on Amendments to the Bill
When the Appropriation Bill is discussed in Parliament, no amendments can be made that:
Increase or decrease the amount of the grants already approved.
Change the purpose (destination) of any approved grants or expenditure.
The Presiding officer (Speaker of the Lok Sabha or Chairman of the Rajya Sabha) will decide if any proposed amendment violates this rule. Their decision is final.
Clause 3: Legal Requirement for Withdrawal of Funds
No money can be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund of India unless it is appropriated by law passed through the Appropriation Bill.
This ensures that government spending is legally authorized and that Parliament has the final say on how funds are spent.

Article:
115. Supplementary, additional or excess grants
 (1) The President shall
 (a) If the amount authorised by any law made in accordance with the provisions of article 114 to be expended for a particular service for the current financial year is found to be insufficient for the purposes of that year or when a need has arisenduring the current financial year for supplementary or additional expenditure upon some new service not contemplated in the annual financial statement for that year, or
 (b) if any money has been spent on any service during a financial year in excess of the amount granted for that service and for that year, cause to be laid before both the Houses of Parliament another statement showing the estimated amount of that expenditure or cause to be presented to the House of the People a demand for such excess, as the case may be
 (2) The provisions of articles 112, 113 and 114 shall have effect in relation to any such statement and expenditure or demand and also to any law to be made authorising the appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of India to meet such expenditure or the grant in respect of such demand as they have effect in relation to the annual financial statement and the expenditure mentioned therein or to a demand for a grant and the law to be made for the authorisation of appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of India to meet such expenditure or grant
Title: Article 115 - Supplementary, Additional, or Excess Grants
Description:
If the government needs more funds than initially allocated in the Budget, it can ask Parliament for Supplementary Grants to cover the extra expenses.
Article 115: Supplementary, Additional, or Excess Grants
Article 115 of the Indian Constitution provides a process for the government to request additional funds during the financial year if the initial allocation is insufficient or if extra expenses arise. It ensures that Parliament has control over how the government's budget is adjusted.

Clause 1: Circumstances for Additional Grants
The President, if the following situations arise, will submit a request to Parliament for supplementary, additional, or excess grants:

(a) If the funds authorized for a particular service (as per the Appropriation Bill) are found to be insufficient for the current financial year.
For example, if a project faces unforeseen costs or the government needs extra funds for a service, such as healthcare during a pandemic.
(b) If the government spends more than the approved budget on a service during the year.
For instance, if the government has already exceeded the initially allocated funds for a department, it will need extra authorization from Parliament to cover the excess expenditure.
In either case, the President will:

Lay before Parliament a statement showing the additional amount of expenditure required.
Alternatively, a demand will be made in the Lok Sabha for the excess amount that has been spent.
Clause 2: Procedural Application
The process for obtaining these supplementary, additional, or excess grants follows the same procedures as the Annual Financial Statement (Article 112), Demands for Grants (Article 113), and the Appropriation Bill (Article 114).
This means that Parliament will review and approve the additional expenditure just as it would the regular budget.
The process involves:
Discussing and approving the extra funds.
Introducing a law for the appropriation (withdrawal) of funds from the Consolidated Fund of India to meet the new expenditure.

Title: Article 116: Votes on Account, Votes of Credit, and Exceptional Grants
Description:
This article addresses the need for the government to make advance or emergency funding requests in situations where regular budget approval processes cannot be completed on time. It allows the government to access funds when there are urgent or unforeseen expenses.

Clause 1: Powers of the House of the People
The House of the People (Lok Sabha) is empowered to make certain kinds of grants in specific situations, even before the formal approval processes (as outlined in Articles 113 and 114) are completed:

Grant in Advance (Votes on Account)

The House can approve a temporary grant for part of a financial year while the full budget approval process is still pending.
This ensures that essential government functions can continue smoothly without waiting for the full passage of the budget.
Example: If the new budget is delayed but the government needs funds for ongoing services like salaries or infrastructure, the House can approve a vote on account to meet these needs.
Grant for Unexpected Demand (Votes of Credit)

In cases where there is an unexpected financial emergency, such as a natural disaster or a national security crisis, the House can approve funds even if the exact details of the expenditure are unclear or too large to fit within the normal budget process.
Example: If a sudden, large-scale natural disaster requires immediate relief, the House may approve an emergency fund (votes of credit) without needing detailed breakdowns.
Exceptional Grant

The House can approve a one-time exceptional grant that is not part of the regular, recurring expenses of the government for that financial year.
Example: A special grant for a major infrastructure project or an unforeseen expenditure that does not fit into the annual budget.
In each of these cases, Parliament is authorized to make laws for the withdrawal of money from the Consolidated Fund of India to cover these grants.

Clause 2: Procedure for Making Grants
Even though these grants are made under exceptional circumstances, the provisions of Articles 113 and 114 (which outline the procedure for voting on grants and appropriating funds) still apply. This means:

The grants must be reviewed, debated, and passed by the House.
Laws to authorize the appropriation of money from the Consolidated Fund of India must be made according to the procedures outlined in the Constitution, ensuring proper checks and balances.

Article:
117. Special provisions as to financial Bills
 (1) A Bill or amendment making provision for any of the matters specified in sub clauses (a) to (f) of clause ( 1 ) of article 110 shall not be introduced or moved except on the recommendation of the President and a Bill making such provision shall not be introduced in the Council of States: Provided that no recommendation shall be required under this clause for the moving of an amendment making provision for the reduction or abolition of any tax
 (2) A Bill or amendment shall not be deemed to make provision for any of the matters aforesaid by reason only that it provides for the imposition of fines or other pecuniary penalties, or for the demand or payment of fees for licences or fees for services rendered, or by reason that it provides for the imposition, abolition, remission, alteration or regulation of any tax by any local authority or body for local purposes
 (3) A Bill which, if enacted and brought into operation, would involve expenditure from the consolidated Fund of India shall not be passed by either House of Parliament unless the President has recommended to that House the consideration of the Bill Procedure Generally
Title: Article 117 - Special Provisions as to Financial Bills
Description:
Money Bills (those related to taxes, loans, and expenditure) can only be introduced in the Lok Sabha (Lower House) with the President's recommendation.
Article 117: Special Provisions as to Financial Bills
This article lays down specific rules for financial bills in the Indian Parliament, particularly with regard to the approval of expenditures from the Consolidated Fund of India and the recommendation of the President.

Clause 1: Restrictions on the Introduction of Certain Financial Bills
Presidential Recommendation Required

A financial bill (or an amendment to a bill) that deals with matters listed in Article 110, Clause 1(a) to (f) (related to the imposition, regulation, and spending of taxes, or borrowing of money) cannot be introduced or moved in Parliament without the recommendation of the President.
This ensures that financial matters, particularly those that directly impact government revenue and expenditure, are introduced with the President's prior approval, which represents the executive branch’s consent.
A financial bill with such provisions cannot be introduced in the Council of States (Rajya Sabha) either. It must start in the House of the People (Lok Sabha).
Exceptions for Certain Amendments

The clause makes an exception: No Presidential recommendation is needed for moving an amendment to a bill if the amendment reduces or abolishes a tax. This allows Parliament to discuss and pass amendments that aim to reduce taxes without needing prior approval from the President.
Clause 2: What Does Not Count as a Financial Bill
A bill or amendment that introduces provisions for penalties, fines, fees for licenses, or taxes imposed by local authorities (for local purposes) does not count as a financial bill, even if it touches on taxes or fees.
Essentially, the clause clarifies that local taxes or fees for services (e.g., licensing fees) imposed by local authorities do not make a bill subject to the special provisions for financial bills, meaning these bills can proceed with fewer restrictions.
Clause 3: Recommendation for Bills Involving Expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of India
If a bill involves expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of India (i.e., it requires the government to spend money from the central fund), it cannot be passed by either House of Parliament unless the President has recommended the consideration of the bill.
This ensures that any spending from the Consolidated Fund is authorized by the executive (the President) before Parliament discusses or approves it.

Article:
118. Rules of procedure
 (1) Each House of Parliament may make rules for regulations, subject to the provisions of this Constitution, its procedure and the conduct of its business
 (2) Until rules are made under clause ( 1 ), the rules of procedure and standing orders in force immediately before the commencement of this Constitution with respect to the Legislature of the Dominion of India shall have effect in relation to Parliament subject to such modifications and adaptations as may be made therein by the Chairman of the Council of States or the Speaker of the House of the People, as the case may be
 (3) The President, after consultation with the Chairman of the Council of States and the Speaker of the House of the People, may make rules as to the procedure with respect to joint sittings of, and communications between, the two Houses
 (4) At a joint sitting of the two Houses the Speaker of the House of the People, or in his absence such person as may be determined by rules of procedure made under clause ( 3 ), shall preside
Title: Article 118: Rules of Procedure
Description:
This article gives Parliament the authority to make its own rules regarding how it conducts its business, regulates its procedures, and handles joint sittings between the two Houses. It also lays down specific provisions regarding the rules for joint sittings and the presiding officer at such sittings.

Clause 1: Rules for Procedure and Conduct of Business
Each House of Parliament (i.e., the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha) has the power to make its own rules for the procedure and conduct of its business, as long as these rules do not contradict the Constitution.
These rules can cover the organization of debates, voting procedures, motions, questioning, and other aspects of parliamentary functioning.
Clause 2: Interim Rules
Interim rules: If a House has not yet made its own rules, the rules and standing orders that were in force immediately before the Constitution came into effect (during the time of the Dominion of India) will still apply. However, these can be modified or adapted by:
The Chairman of the Rajya Sabha (Council of States), or
The Speaker of the Lok Sabha (House of the People).
This clause ensures that there is no vacuum in the parliamentary procedures during the transition period, and business can still be conducted as per the previous rules.
Clause 3: Rules for Joint Sittings and Communication Between Houses
The President of India has the authority, after consulting both the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha and the Speaker of the Lok Sabha, to make rules for joint sittings of the two Houses and for the communication between the Houses.
This is particularly important for matters like joint discussions or voting on issues that require the approval of both Houses together (e.g., in cases where both Houses cannot agree on a Bill, they may meet in a joint session).
The rules would help in coordination and smooth functioning of joint sittings.
Clause 4: Presiding Officer at Joint Sitting
At a joint sitting of the two Houses of Parliament, the Speaker of the Lok Sabha will preside over the session. If the Speaker is absent, then the person who has been designated by the rules of procedure made under clause (3) will preside instead.

Article: 119. Regulation by law of procedure in Parliament in relation to financial business Parliament may, for the purpose of the timely completion of financial business, regulate by law the procedure of, and the conduct of business in, each House of Parliament in relation to any financial matter or to any Bill for the appropriation of moneys out of the consolidated Fund of India, and, if and so far as any provision of any law so made is inconsistent with any rule made by a House of Parliament under clause ( 1 ) of Article 118 or with any rule or standing order having effect in relation to Parliament under clause ( 2 ) of that article, such provision shall prevail
Title: Article 119 - Regulation by Law of Procedure in Parliament in Relation to Financial Business
Description: Parliament can make laws to regulate the procedures for financial matters, such as the passage of the Budget and financial proposals, ensuring they are handled in a timely manner.

Article:
120. Language to be used in Parliament
 (1) Notwithstanding anything in Part XVII, but subject to the Article 348, business in Parliament shall be transacted in Hindi or in English: Provided that the Chairman of the Council of States or Speaker of the House of the People, or Person acting as such, as the Case may be, may permit any member who cannot adequately express himself in Hindi or in English to address the House in his mother tongue
 (2) Unless Parliament by Law otherwise provides, this article shall, after the expiration of a period of fifteen years from the commencement of this Constitution, have effect as if the words or in English were omitted therefrom
Title: Article 120 - Language to be Used in Parliament
Description:
Business in Parliament can be conducted in Hindi or English.
If a member doesn't know these languages, they can speak in their regional language, as permitted by the Speaker.

Article: 121. Restriction on discussion in Parliament No discussions shall take place in Parliament with respect to the conduct of any Judge of the Supreme Court or of a High Court in the discharge of his duties expect upon a motion for presenting an address to the President praying for the removal of the Judge as hereinafter provided
Title: Article 121 - Restriction on Discussion in Parliament
Description: Parliament cannot discuss the conduct of judges of the Supreme Court or High Courts while they are performing their judicial functions, except in cases where a judge’s removal is being considered.

Article:
122. Courts not to inquire into proceedings of Parliament
 (1) The validity of any proceedings in Parliament shall not be called in question on the ground of any alleged irregularity of procedure
 (2) No officer or member of Parliament in whom powers are vested by or under this Constitution for regulating procedure or the conduct of business, or for maintaining order, in Parliament shall be subject to the jurisdiction of any court in respect of the exercise by him of those powers CHAPTER III LEGISLATIVE POWERS OF THE PRESIDENT
Title: Article 122 - Courts Not to Inquire into Proceedings of Parliament
Description:
The courts cannot question or interfere in the proceedings of Parliament, even if the procedure followed by Parliament was irregular.
This ensures Parliament’s autonomy in its internal matters.

Article:
123. Power of President to promulgate Ordinances during recess of Parliament
 (1) If at any time, except when both Houses of Parliament are in session, the President is satisfied that circumstances exist which render it necessary for him to take immediate action, he may promulgate such Ordinance as the circumstances appear to him to require
 (2) An Ordinance promulgated under this article shall have the same force and effect as an Act of Parliament, but every such Ordinance
 (a) shall be laid before both House of Parliament and shall cease to operate at the expiration of six weeks from the reassemble of Parliament, or, if before the expiration of that period resolutions disapproving it are passed by both Houses, upon the passing of the second of those resolutions; and
 (b) may be withdrawn at any time by the President Explanation Where the Houses of Parliament are summoned to reassemble on different dates, the period of six weeks shall be reckoned from the later of those dates for the purposes of this clause
 (3) If and so far as an Ordinance under this article makes any provision which Parliament would not under this Constitution be competent to enact, it shall be void CHAPTER IV THE UNION JUDICIARY
Title: Article 123: Power of President to Promulgate Ordinances During Recess of Parliament
Description:
This article provides the President of India with the power to issue Ordinances when Parliament is not in session, in cases where immediate action is needed. An Ordinance is a temporary law made by the President, and it has the same effect as an Act of Parliament but with specific limitations.

Clause 1: Conditions for Promulgating an Ordinance
When both Houses of Parliament are not in session, and the President believes that urgent action is required due to certain circumstances, he can promulgate an Ordinance.
This power allows the President to make laws during a recess (when Parliament is not in session) when a delay in legislation could be detrimental or harmful.
The President can take action based on the situation and needs of the moment, even if Parliament is not available to discuss or pass a Bill.
Clause 2: Characteristics of the Ordinance
Force and effect: An Ordinance has the same power and legal effect as an Act of Parliament (a law passed by Parliament).

However, it is not permanent. It will automatically cease to have effect under the following conditions:

Six weeks after Parliament reconvenes, unless Parliament approves it before then.
Resolutions disapproving the Ordinance: If both Houses of Parliament pass resolutions rejecting the Ordinance, it will cease to have effect once the second resolution is passed.
Power to withdraw: The President can also withdraw the Ordinance at any time, even before the six-week period ends.

Explanation: If Parliament is reconvened on different dates, the six-week period is calculated from the later date of the two reconvening dates.

Clause 3: Restrictions on Ordinances
An Ordinance cannot make laws that Parliament would not be competent to enact under the Constitution. If it does, such a provision in the Ordinance will be void (invalid).
For example, if the Ordinance violates any constitutional limitations or exceeds the powers granted to Parliament, it will be considered null and void.
